comments.commentBody:
@TDK: Agreed about your points. Also unsaid, but has been suggested, is that Maradona, in his unhinged state, *chose willfully* to play Messi in what was not his optimal position so as to not be eclipsed as the best player Argentina ever produced. Witness his sniping at Pele as a sign of Maradona's basic insecurity, and the idea doesn't seem so far fetched.
Now there is no excuse for Argentina to not build around Messi, and being in Brazil might just bring out the best in not only Messi, but in all of the Albicelestes. Yes, a transcendent Spain *might* render all other questions moot, but the draw will have a lot to say about how things shake out, as will circumstances, form, and key injuries. It will be fascinating to see.

I went to two games this September. I went to a Wednesday night game against the Phils that was the last game of the season pitched by Matt Marvey, who went seven strong, and the only hit he gave up was an HR leading off the game by Jimmy Rollins. There were 3000 people in the stands, TOPS, and a disturbing proportion of them were in Phillies' garb. I went to the last home game of the season, a Wednesday DAY game after school was back in session. It was the day Dickey won his 20th against the Pirates. There were at LEAST 25,000 in the stands, and few were in Pirates' gear.
If the Wilpons can't do the math on putting fannies in the seats, then they're somehow even stupider than I had imagined, which is hard to even conceptualize. David Wright played, and homered, in both games. I know it was *an occasion,* but Dickey was responsible, I'd say, for putting at least 20,000 fannies in the seats on this day. At an average price of $25/ticket, which I consider conservative, the additional take for the Mets on tickets ALONE was half a million dollars, not to mention parking and concessions. Multiply that by 16 home starts for Dickey, and the Mets should be able to make $8-10 million per season on the days that Dickey starts over any other starter (even Johan). Hello? Anybody home? Isn't Saul Katz an accountant by profession? Can't he figure this out? To paraphrase Jimmy Breslin (quoting Casey Stengel): "Can't anybody here think through this game?"

Yanks won the pennant in 64, but lost the World Series in 7 to the Cardinals.
The Yankee$ are willing to pay top dollar for one-year contracts. They can spend to the moon this season, but in the comment train of another post on this blog, they MUST be below $189M for the 2014 season. With A-Roid, Teixeira and Sabathia already under contract for 2014 at over $23M each, and Cano being a free agent after 2013, prospectively commanding, for even numbers' sake, $22M, that would mean the Yankee$ would have $95M of the $189M they need for the 40 man roster PLUS benefit costs, tied up in a mere four players. Good luck constructing a team that won't be dismal under that stricture...
I think the collapse you envision would be more likely in 2014, but success in 2013 will also hinge on maintaining the health of a pretty old squad.

Ichiro demonstrated ample ability to reach the short porch almost at will in his stint with the Yankee$ last year. He also played day-in-day-out down the stretch. A good signing if Ichiro knows he's in it for one year only, with ZERO chance of returning afterward (see $189M salary limit for 2014, above).
Had a look at the Red Sox' outfield of Ellsbury, Crawford and Victorino?
Win what World Series? They lost to the Dodgers in 1963 and to the Cardinals in 1964. After that, no World Series until 1976, when they got swept by the Big Red Machine.

Agree with you regarding A-Rod and the fact the team is saddled with his bad contract. However, I must correct one point - the Yanks lost the 1964 WS to the Cards.

Yanks fan since 1965 - the start of the years "wandering in the desert".

Ray in Maine
Cone, Martinez, Clemens.  You're welcome.
Jeff Wilpon has a high school diploma. That's all. No higher education. It shows.
The Yankees lost the 64 series to the Cardinals in 7 games. Mantle batted .400 with three home runs.

This is crazy.  The one reason fans came to the ballpark in any numbers at all was to watch Dickey pitch.  He's a knuckleballer, so even at his age there is no real reason to believe he can't come close to (if not match or possibly even exceed) his 2012 performance for the next couple of years.  So give the guy his two-year extension, and give him what he's worth for years two and three as you have him a way-below-market bargain for 2013.   Or, if you're offered a deal you can't refuse then trade him, but do it already.
Perhaps photo shows after follow-through of lefty swing.
No, Martin, not with left hand low on bat.  It's a warm-up swing from right side.
When did Ichiro start batting righty?

Sheryl: I am 100% agreed with you. Nobody is making the argument that the Mets have any chance to contend, although they did for the entire first half of last year.
But in rebuilding, it is important to prepare players, particularly young ones, to win. Terry Collins is a great handler of young players, and he has an expectation about the proper way to play the game, and the attendant attention to detail. Guys like Wright and especially Dickey, are exemplars of what Collins is trying to produce out of all of his players, and, in that regard, they are as valuable to the Mets going forward as, say, Mattingly was in 1995 to Jeter, Rivera and Pettitte going forward.
Even though the Mets young arms are not knuckleballers, Dickey knows a LOT about how to get guys out. How to persevere without your best stuff (his 20th win last year was a perfect example-fell behind with a poor knuckler. Got guys out with fastballs, changeups, and an occasional curve, and won on a Wright three run dinger), and how to prepare professionally. He bunt, he hits, he fields as well as any pitcher in the game. Why would the Mets NOT find all of those important blocks to build upon? Only the Wilpons know, and they'll never open their mouths on the subject to avoid proving their ignorance to all within the sound of their voices.

I've been a Mets fan since 1964, and watch just about every game on MLB.com. But if they don't extend Dickey's contract, I'm done. This organization is an embarrassment, and the way they've treated Dickey is appalling. Maybe I'm wrong, but I don't recall any team heading to the winter meetings and essentially telling the world, "Hey, we're really eager to trade our Cy Young Award-winner. What have you got for us?" And Alderson's attempt at humor with the "box of chocolates" line prior to the start of the meetings was tone deaf.

Dickey is one of the few reasons to watch this team. But it's not just what he brings to the field that makes him so compelling. It's his attitude, his demeanor, his character, his approach to the game, and his life experience. He's a real "mensch," the adult in the room, the kind of player who can lead by example. These kinds of people are few and far between, especially in sports; their intangibles can't be measured with statistics.

Dickey's given the Mets three quality seasons, including this past magical one. But even if he never quite matches the heights he did in 2012, he can still be invaluable. With a young pitching staff full of potential (and on the Mets, we know how potential usually goes), they need Dickey as an anchor. It makes no sense that the team seems so eager to trade him. Yet all indications are that's exactly what they want. And if that happens, I have no desire to root for a team that's bankrupt in every sense of the word.
Ichiro is a master batsman and more importantly still is. He will win games period. One year is money well spent
If the Mets lose Dickey, I can't imagine watching this team. What will the new slogan be? Come Out To Citi-Field; That Noise You Hear is Flushing?

Wilpon and Katz had to plead in a court of law under oath that they were incompetent businessmen and ignorant investors to get out from under a billion dollars worth of claims by the Madoff trustee. They really are just two bit con-men and chiselers holding on to the Mets and SNY network while nickel and dime-ing players and scamming fans until they can make their final score.  Alderson should get out while he still has some reputation left.

Trading Dickey is an enormous risk when you consider how many previously established players were sub-standard upon coming to New York; Jason Bay is a prime example. I favored signing Wright because he has proven he can excel here. Dickey has done likewise. No matter how good the prospects or everyday players offered up for Dickey, there's a significant chance they will disappoint.

Before you anoint the Nix as champions, bear in mind that the Nix are exacty one QUARTER of the way through the season. Will the aging players hold up to the rigors of 63 more regular season games, and four rounds of playoffs? Will an eventual returen of Stoudemire change the chemistry for the worse? That has happened before.
Suzuki is a pro and a Hall of Famer. He showed surprising power when tempted with the short porch in right. But when will Rodriguez be back, and will his return disturb Youk? Will Jeter really be ready for the beginning of the season? That is a key question. Will Suzuki still have that renewed sense of purpose knowing that he has ZERO chance of returning to the Yank$ in 2014? Will his soon to be 40 year old legs stay healthy, particularly in light of the necessity of playing 18 division games on turf? Same question for renewed purpose for Youk, since he, too, has ZERO chance of making the Yank$ $189M payroll for 2014.
how will the Yankees deal with being more lopsidedly lefty hitting than ever in recent memory? There are now a pretty fair number of good lefty starters in the division. Will that make a difference?

anyone bashing "age" need look no further than mid town, and the old men of the knicks, in first place, and lookin' good.
suzuki was great for the yanks, and would be great again, and make the team super exciting. he played with a renewed purpose, and hunger, like a young guy with something to prove. yooook would actually have the same renewed purpose, in his case to stick it to the sox. former discarded old sox acquired by the yanks have historically shined, like damon, louis tiant, clemens, and boggs. as much as i despised youklis when he was against us, we all would really love him as he's poking the sox in the eye! i agree with another poster about how great a speedy outfield of grandy, gardy, and suzuki will be. go yanks. they will surprise a lot of people this year.
If R.A. is lucky he will be traded and get away from the cancerous leadership of Freddy, Jeff and Sandy the puppet.  R.A. is a class act.  His employers, not so much.
I'm sorry--do the Mets have such outstanding talent that they can give short shrift to the Cy Young winner?  Pathetic.

If the Mets decide to let Dickey play out his contract this year without signing him to an extension, I would hope that he continues to bust his butt for the team and its fans for one more year.  That is the professional thing to do - he is under contract and being paid to play.  He talks about it being personal, but R.A, c'mon man - we all know that pro sports is strictly business.  The Mets are under no obligations whatsoever to extend your contract (or to not trade you for that matter).  You and us fans want the Mets to keep you for the next few years, but if they don't, we'll all have to deal with it and move on.

I remember when the NY Giants let Hoyt Wilhelm go because of his age. The knuckleballer went on to brilliant seasons with the Orioles as a starter.

Sandy Alderson was chosen by thelDartmouth Alumni Council as a candidate for trustee. That alone should indicate unfitness for making critical decisions. (By rthe way, he lost the election.)

the owners of the mets are bungling, upper class twit, idiots. they've made the mets the laughing stocks of baseball. too bad dickey can't fire them, instead of them not hiring him. he's a class individual, with real intelligence, and grace, plus, he's a winner amongst a bunch of losers. so add that up, and you know that the twits will blow it, for sure.

Do the right thing! R.A. is a special player with an incredible upside.
He's inspirational for all the right reasons, on and off the field.
Get it done. Period.

comments.parentUserDisplayName: Blue and Orange and No Black
comments.commentBody: amen

comments.userDisplayName: Blue and Orange and No Black
comments.commentBody: It is time for the Wilpons to sell the Mets and just go away.

One of my favorite commentaries on professional sports came from the film version of North Dallas Forty, in a heated statement from a player to a coach: "When we say it's a game, you call it business. When we call it business, you say it's a game."
Good Luck R.A., we miss you here in Minnesota!
